Review: ‚ÄúDoes any fraction of these women still exist?‚Äù ‚ÄúOf course! Almost everything.‚Äù The key to this movie comes from Bobbie at the 4th of July picnic when she questions why there are no Black people around. I was surprised to read that others thought that Joanna acquiesced because she trusted Walter. Joanna did not become a robot to please Walter, Joanna became a robot because she realized that Stepford was a very literal microcosm of the real world and how nice would it be to just give the fuck up and not have to figure out who you are. Misogyny is so well embedded in our culture that Joanna could never be confident that the Wives weren‚Äôt happy; they had achieved peak, perfect femininity, doesn‚Äôt that count for something? Walter‚Äôs hesitation to fembot Joanna endorses this reading: he knows that he will never be happy without Joanna as Joanna, but heteronormativity and gender conformation calls to him like the Green Goblin mask. Even love isn‚Äôt enough to overcome patriarchy and white supremacy. Joanna and Walter‚Äôs gleeful conformity to the robotic Stepford life shows us that they understand that their genders, marriage, and parenthood must be performed. Claire‚Äôs final reveal and the knocking-off of Mike‚Äôs head shows us that those core beliefs behind Stepford do not come from individuals but from societal stories. Unfortunately, the metaphor gets muddied by the ending scene of the Wives waking up and the overtly campy tone. We also didn‚Äôt see Joanna suffering as the head of the company, so Claire‚Äôs ending speech comes across as insanity instead of frustration that the world is so nebulous that being brainless seems easier. Beautiful performances from Nicole Kidman, Bette Midler, and Glenn Close. Feels unnervingly contemporary. I totally understand Olivia Wilde‚Äôs excitement to make a version for the 2020s. The one liners were great and I had a fabulous time!!

The role of the lighting obv changed a lot from version to version, and I think it‚Äôs because as filmmaking got more advanced it became more tempting to replace the use of light and shadows with more complicated (?) visual effects. Skarsgard is a master of his craft, but Nosferatu was scary in this version because of the nastiness they were able to cake on to Skarsgard. Nosferatu was scary in 1922 because of Murnau‚Äôs use of shadow to impose that figure over everything, from Wisberg to God himself. Eggers fell a little short here but it‚Äôs understandable I loved that this Nosferatu is finally about Ellen!!! Ellen calls Orlok to her when she is young, Knock sent Ellen‚Äôs husband to Orlok, Orlok comes to Wisberg in pursuit of Ellen, and the lens through which the entire movie is shot is very obviously Ellen‚Äôs. Thomas (and Friedrich and Anne and Sievers and) all tell her to be quiet and stop sharing her stupid dumb nightmares and to get over herself. Ellen‚Äôs sexuality is sinful (her father told her so very literally) and disgusting, and her marriage with Thomas reorients her darkness into something she can understand because her sexuality is finally permissible. Thomas learns to believe his wife (ugh) and seems to understand her, but only when it‚Äôs just too late. Ellen seeks understanding from a female friend who instead rebuffs her with cries of holiness and God. Her friend‚Äôs nasty nasty husband thinks restraining and drugging her makes sense, because it‚Äôs the only way he could stop her from ‚Äútearing the room into ribbons‚Äù (how inconvenient!). Anna and Friedrich‚Äôs sexuality is Puritan Perfect: look how they have gone forth and multiplied! Thomas and Ellen can only scrabble at each other‚Äôs clothes in their friends‚Äô foyer after Anna and Friedrich left to put their perfect blonde babies to bed.¬† Van Helsing, I mean Von Frantz, is the only person who gets asymptotically close to understanding Ellen, and it is because he approaches her with the kindness and grace to find her uniqueness. She is not just a Woman or Wife, but a conduit for a demon, and that makes her deserving of attention and understanding. In a moment of really beautiful connection that showcases Defoe and Depp, Von Frantz tells Ellen ‚ÄúIn heathen times, you might have been a great priestess of Isis, yet, in this strange and modern world your purpose is of greater worth: you are our salvation.‚Äù Heathen times‚Äîfor which the Romani are our stand in‚Äîare literally without God, but also show women with knowledge and agency. (1) Ellen called Orlok to her // her sexual desire is the origin of the curse. (2) Ellen tries to share her knowledge and nobody believes her, meaning that Orlok successfully arrives in Wisberg and brings the plague // society represses that desire and suffers for it (3) Ellen reasserts that she can put an end to it all // society very literally suffers and degrades because of their dismissal of a woman (4) Ellen finally, of her own free will, distracts Orlok by feeding him and laying with him until sunrise, dying at the last moment // Ellen exerts her agency for the first time and society is better for it, but she dies before she can experience the fruits of her pain. If Orlok is Ellen‚Äôs spirit or sexual desire or sin, the moment she fully accepts that rot is when the plague is lifted. Eggers was completely spot on with this shift of focus, and the story is much stronger for it.¬† Some unfortunate negatives: - So much ~atmosphere~, not much substance. I spent a bunch of the first act wondering why tf the Hutters were so down bad that Thomas would spend 6 weeks crossing the Carpathians¬† - No bow for the Romani storyline??? You‚Äôre going to make this huge declaration about believing women and then miss the entire point of the Romani being there????????????????? Despite the huge strides in character for Ellen, I‚Äôm not so sure that Eggers made a net improvement on either the Murnau or Herzog versions. My rookie mistake was not narrowing down a list of movies from which to choose prior to the mushrooms hitting, so I frantically sped (ha) through my watchlist hoping to find something. Run Lola Run? No, couldn't deal with any real tension. Tron: Legacy? No, I needed something good. Speed Racer? That old movie my brother (Henry) and godbrother (Crash) would watch ad nauseam in the background while I hung out at my godmother's house? Sure. Fuck it. It's the Wachowski sisters and the internet says it's trippy. Here I sit 135 minutes later with tears streaming down my face. I sent Henry at least 75 texts while watching this, half of which simply said "aura aura aura." Speed Racer himself joins the ranks of the coolest protagonists of all time, and has inspired me to make a list with those characters. "Hey, I have a meeting with my accountant in a few. Yeah, I would recommend him, want his number? His name is Speed Racer" like C'MON, what else was that kid gonna do? Its visuals were so dialed in that you could mistake them for Kid Pix excellence. They grew frenetic alongside the story and tightened back up without you even noticing at first. The different races had their own visual cues; I loved how fluid and loose the colors got during Casa Cristo, lines snaking all over the screen and dust flying like they were driving along the Fury Road. The Grand Prix itself had me up and off the couch. Speed flipping the cars as he passed the cameras made me gasp. I mean, what else are movies for? But despite the visuals and despite the excitement of the finishes, all I could think of while watching this movie was Henry and Crash in my godmother's living room with their hot wheels. I am no race car driver, but I've been spending a lot of time recently reflecting on what it means to be an older sister. There's a moment when Spritle asks if he can come with Speed, and Speed finally understands something fundamental about both Rex and about being an adult. He turns to his younger brother and tells him ‚Äúyou‚Äôll understand when it‚Äôs your turn.‚Äù That line forced me to pause the movie so I could get out a few wracking sobs without covering up the dialogue. I think every person has been told ‚Äúyou‚Äôll understand when it‚Äôs your turn,‚Äù and that feels frustrating and devastating and isolating. I now spend much of my time chasing art that gives me that feeling.¬†Shelley wrestled with topics around gender/sex that a na√Øve fifteen year old me thought women of yore must have only approached imprecisely and indelicately. I remember being so shocked by Shelley‚Äôs care and creativity when exploring ideas like the creation of life (and its sanctity), how we are reflected in the world by our creations, and how women operate in a world that so values them for their ability to create particular things (people, certainty not novels). I‚Äôm embarrassed to say I haven‚Äôt read the book in ~5 years, so I will plow through the aforementioned copy and update my review if my opinions change. I am not an adaptation purist, and am of two minds here. One is that it feels as though this adaptation is for those who love the book: Elizabeth serves to bring in more explicit ties between the Creature and parenthood, the Creature is very literally a construction of ideal masculinity, and Frankenstein‚Äôs ego is all the Prometheus-ity someone familiar with the book would need. If you‚Äôve read the book, this is a beautiful visualization of a world with which you are familiar. Guillermo del Toro was made to make such a movie, and we had fun for two and a half hours! The other part of me, however, is left disappointed by the lack of adherence to the most interesting parts of Shelley‚Äôs novel. Name: Sentimental Value
Review: "It's hard to love someone who is full of anger." Sometimes it‚Äôs painful for me to engage with art that shows me an unflattering version of myself. Nora is intentionally unreadable and wants nothing more than a home. She desperately wants those around her to see her, and yet nothing is scarier to her. She asks her father why he disappeared and how he could possibly think he knows her because the alternative‚Äîhim knowing her and choosing to stay away‚Äîis much, much worse. She is only able to express herself through her art, because the moment someone indicates they want to try knowing her is the moment she withdraws. Nora and Rachel‚Äôs conversation about whether the character‚Äôs sadness is ‚Äúsuch an overwhelming part of her‚Äù and is ‚Äújust the cause of everything, or is‚Ä¶ a symptom of something deeper‚Äù is the closest we see Nora allow someone to get to her, and that‚Äôs only because her defenses were down. I‚Äôm happy to say I (mostly) no longer feel like Nora; my desperation to be seen is turning into a love for those who see me, and I‚Äôm much better at letting more of myself be known now. When Gustav is asking Nora to be in his movie, he tells her that ‚Äúit‚Äôs hard to love someone who is full of anger,‚Äù but that is exactly what this movie makes it so easy to do. In a story about how artists use their art to convey emotions they otherwise have no access to, we see Gustav literally try to script and direct a repair with his eldest daughter. She refuses to participate in the movie Gustav is asking her to star in, but is still dragged into the emotional turmoil brought by her father‚Äôs return. The movie is the vehicle for understanding whether she participates in it or not (sidebar: it's funny that I am pulling a Gustav here, and using a movie as a safer proxy to talk about my year and my feelings). Nora and Gustav are flawed and actively make it hard to care for them, but we see (far more than they do) how easy it is to love them. Agnes is the key here, and her ability to show her love for her family members gives both Gustav and Nora an example they tentatively hope they can follow. Stalin has that quote about decades where nothing happens and weeks where decades happen; this year has felt like a series of weeks-where-decades-happen for me, and it felt like Sentimental Value portrayed the same thing. Sometimes we are pulled‚Äîready or not‚Äîinto growth and change and progress that feels stagnant while within it and profound once you‚Äôre out. This year it has felt like time keeps bunching up into these weird, shattering moments. Many of these moments were about being a sister and what it means to care for others, so I'd like to thank Trier for reaching into my brain while writing this movie. When Nora said she didn‚Äôt need therapy because she knew too much about herself already, I was reminded of times when I‚Äôve felt like Nora and knew, subconsciously, that cracking the door would lead to more change than I felt ready for. Nora‚Äôs attempt to keep the door held was visibly exhausting and clearly tormented her, and yet it was clear that Nora was trying to take care of herself in the only way she knew how. Instead of an overwrought self-pity party, Renate Reinsve‚Äôs astounding performance makes us sympathize with Nora without feeling frustrated at her emotional constipation. That final scene of the Borgs actually filming the movie made me cry for many reasons, one of which was that it was an example of how things that previously felt impossible become real once you‚Äôre able to untangle your own emotional knot a little bit. I certainly imposed this feeling on Nora a bit here, but this year I‚Äôve continuously found myself in situations I thought myself unequipped to handle, only to surprise myself by how well I navigate them. Much like Nora‚Äôs stage fright in the first scene, sometimes it doesn‚Äôt matter if you‚Äôre ready to go out on stage because you just have to go.

Name: The Worst Person in the World
Review: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure I remember things about you that you've forgotten.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd the other way around.‚Äù ‚ÄúYeah. When I'm gone, all that stuff about you will go with me.‚Äù How are we meant to keep living with this trail of selves and relationships stretching so far behind us? What happens when we're the person who set those things down, and we don't know if we were right to do so? I think a shallower reading of the movie is "some things end, life moves on," but has anything really ended for Julie? Did she ever move forward, or just on to new versions of the same? I just watched Millennium Mambo, and found it connected to this movie well. Both are an unflattering self-portrait that isn‚Äôt begging for absolution, just trying to see clearly. They‚Äôre about looking back at a younger self without fully disowning her or excusing her, just letting her stand there in all her avoidance, as a work in progress. I didn't see as much of myself in Julie as others seem to, and I'm worried that's not because we're different but is because I, like her, have an ability to self-reflect that ends when we get to the juicy bits. The movie is full of those moments where you can feel Julie hovering at the edge of a hard truth and then choosing motion instead of depth: a new job, a new relationship, a new story about who she is. The "messy young woman" thing sometimes feels overwrought, but watching these movies back to back has really helped me feel less alone in the whole "I'm in my mid/late twenties and don't know what the hell I'm doing" thing I have going on rn. I feel silly typing that, because who doesn't think that when they're my age, but I think that's the point of art like this: taking the most common experiences in the world and showing how we all manage to feel like we're the only person going through it. The styling and visuals make it really hard to not Google "Norway visa requirements." Renate Reinsve and Anders Danielsen Lie doing some truly incredible work. Beautiful, beautiful movie.

And maybe go to the beach.‚Äù - ‚ÄúGet ready. Tighten your seatbelts.‚Äù - ‚ÄúUgandan Ghetto Air Force‚Äù In the age of generative AI, I've turned to art more and more to try and feel that connection to the greater human experience. Sometimes I'm crying in museums in front of paintings, sometimes I'm listening to drivers license while wondering how heartbreak feels the same for everybody but so so different each time, and sometimes I'm watching movies that convey a passion and joy for the art form so clearly that my toes curl and my hair stands straight up. Who Killed Captain Alex? is absolutely not "so bad it's good," it's just straight up good. There is so much love for cinema oozing out of every single aspect of it that you can't help but love it. It is an ode to action and to kung fu and to mafia movies and revenge plots. It takes seriously that which other movies had already discarded to the "for satire only pile" (my dad asked if this was released before or after Tropic Thunder). One of the smartest, funniest choices is VJ Emmie. He drags you into the movie with him. In a moment where so much art feels optimized for viewership, I am so so so grateful to get to see art with joy and nerve. You really just have to make things. Get a camera, get a microphone, get some friends, tighten your seatbelts, and have some fun.
